awd_titl_txt: From Common Measures to Measures in Common: A Convening to Enhance Measurement of Outcomes of Afterschool STEM Programs
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
To explore the current state of evaluation and measurement tools for use in afterschool STEM programs, the STEM Hub, with leadership from the University of Washington, the Afterschool Alliance, and the National Girls Collaborative, designed and hosted a convening for afterschool STEM practitioners, researchers, evaluators and stakeholders. The goals of the conference were to (a) articulate and map the range of intended outcomes of afterschool STEM programs; (b) identify how existing measurement and evaluation tools map onto intended outcomes; and (c) identify overlaps, complementarities, and gaps in the available tools in order to provide guidance to practitioners on how and why to select current evaluation tools and researchers on directions for future tool development.

This convening offered leaders in the afterschool STEM field the opportunity to explore the interconnectedness of the wide variety of STEM programs, intended outcomes, and measurement tools that are utilized across communities. The conversations emphasized the importance of recognizing the diversity of interests and capacities of young people, the values of communities, and how to assess both youth outcomes and how well programs uphold community values through their STEM offerings.

Prior to the convening, we developed a literature review that surveyed the breadth of instruments used to measure the success of afterschool and summer STEM programs. The review identified the measures within each instrument, and then grouped together the measures that were common across instruments. This document has already been a tremendous resource for situating the convening within the ongoing work of STEM program research and evaluation. It has been iteratively refined through feedback from participants and will serve as an anchor for the current state of measurement, while pushing the field to continue thinking more critically about the role of education research in moving towards goals of racial equity and social justice. Recently, the literature review was submitted to the Journal of Youth Development and is currently under review. If accepted as a feature article, it will reach an even wider audience of researchers, evaluators, policymakers, and practitioners.

In tandem with the literature review, we created an annotated bibliography focused on centering community values in STEM evaluation. The bibliography compiled resources under several related categories, including culturally responsive evaluation, values-engaged educative evaluation, and orientations to collaborative research and evaluation. Readers will better understand the history of evaluation in STEM programs, as well as innovative approaches to work towards overcoming legacies of racism, sexism, and settler colonialism.

During the convening, participants produced a visual representation that linked afterschool programs, desired outcomes with the constructs that are currently being measured, as well as the instruments used to measure them. This map, which was initially composed with paper, markers, and sticky notes and later digitized, highlighted areas of overlap as well as significant gaps between the current state of research and the needs of communities that have been historically excluded from STEM careers and identities, like communities of color, girls and women, and people with disabilities. As a digital artifact, this resource is able to be disseminated widely to afterschool STEM researchers and practitioners. It has already been immensely useful in helping us see how program evaluations have largely been focused on individual student achievement, and tend to exclude more community-oriented measures like racial equity and community impact.

As a next step, we conducted a follow-up webinar in which attendees were invited to fill out a shared spreadsheet, which included their contact information, resources they could share with the afterschool STEM community, resources they hoped to procure, as well as avenues for continued collaboration. Dozens of attendees have populated the document, indicating a desire to be involved beyond just attending these events, but in continuing to work together to improve STEM education in the United States.

The success of this project has been predicated on disseminating our findings to academic and professional audiences who are interested in afterschool STEM education. We have brought together hundreds of people in the afterschool STEM space to better understand how programs are currently being evaluated and to point at changes that need to be made in order to improve STEM learning outcomes. Through this process, participants are building the knowledge base, skills, and relationships that are necessary to move forward. Products like the literature review and the digital map were developed by research assistants who, by virtue of this work, are becoming more central participants and deepening their expertise in the field. The conversations sparked at the convening are inviting seasoned researchers to consider alternative ways of measuring program success. These are all important examples of professional development that will continue to unfold as we continue our work.
